summary: This Court of Appeal ruling in Ghana addresses a civil motion for stay of execution pending appeal in a landlord-tenant dispute. The plaintiff, Sam Jonah, obtained a summary judgment in the High Court for ejectment and rent arrears against tenant Lord Duodu-Kumi, who challenged the plaintiff's ownership and the legality of USD-denominated rent payments. The Court of Appeal upheld the summary judgment, holding that the tenant was estopped from denying ownership due to prior attornment via rent payments and that USD rent payments before January 1998 did not violate later Bank of Ghana foreign exchange regulations. The court found no triable issues warranting a full trial and rejected claims of irreparable harm, emphasizing that financial inability alone does not justify a stay of execution.
verdict: Application for stay of execution rejected
citations: Sam Jonah v. Lord Duodu-Kumi, C.M. No. 209/98, 21st January 1999
Bank of Ghana Notice No BG/GOV/SEC/98/2
rationaleHighlights: Tenant estopped from challenging landlord's title after attorning by paying rent
Prior conduct and acceptance of new landlord binding
USD rent payments made in 1996 predated January 1998 foreign exchange restrictions
Payments converted to cedis by authorized dealer bank, complying with regulations
No triable issues existed to prevent summary judgment
Financial hardship alone insufficient for stay of execution
Bank of Ghana notice exempted authorized dealer banks
Cheques explicitly showed cedi equivalents, indicating local currency settlement
